climbs.name: Walking On Eggshells
climbs.fa: FTR: Leventhal, Oliphant, Drapper (1992)  FL:  (Rebolted in 2018).

content.protection: 14 Bolts to a chain anchor.A longer draw (23cm) on the third bolt in the hueco will help with rope drag.
content.location: Located on the East side of "The Egg" formation. Access from inside the Corridor. Obvious overhanging line. Clearly bolted. Chain anchor to get down from the top.

content.description: The crux of this route was once avoiding exposure to the clusters of Poison Oak occupying the base of the route, but that threat has been removed. The high level of choss has been mitigated by the cleaning efforts of Jack Marshall and Tony Sartin to the establish the routes "Marshall Law" and "Poached," respectively. The easiest way to access the ledge and anchors on The Egg.

Climb up really good holds, some of which are kind of chossy. Pull a couple of small bulges, all while enjoying just how nice the holds are. Perhaps reachy at times? Could use some cleaning, then it might be 2-3 stars.
content.protection: 7 bolts to a two chain anchor hanging from the egg.
content.location: Start at the base of the pedestal just next to the wooden steps, before reaching the boulders that you have to climb over to get to the first corridor. This route is right of Cereal Killer (which is right of Green Mile), and climbs up much better holds. The anchor is just 5 ft or so right of Cereal Killer.

content.description: An interesting variation that incorporates the challenging beginning of Texas Chainsaw with the exciting finish of Slotterhouse without the thin finish on Texas Chainsaw. Begin on Texas Chainsaw Massacre. Climb up between the two giant cobbles. Continue climbing to clip the 4th bolt of TCM from a softball sized cobble at a weakness. Move left to the right side of the enormous scoop and clip the 5th bolt of Slotterhouse. Finish up Slotterhouse. This is a 6 bolt linkup of Texas Chainsaw Massacre and Slotterhouse.

Texas Chainsaw Massacre begins with a series of good-sized, but

shallow

pockets. Pockets lead to a stance below two large inclusions and the 1st bolt. Continue up the featured face on edges, cobbles, and an occasional pocket. As the angle of the slab decreases so do the number of pockets, and the footholds and handholds become smaller and less secure. Insecure friction, small smooth cobbles, and palming lead to the anchor. The top section once spit off the infamous Medusa for a good twelve foot leader fall, while he was spraying about being a 5.13 climber and how over bolted TCM was.
content.location: This is the 3rd route from the left side of The Egg Cup buttress. Begin at a series of large shallow pockets.

content.description: Begin at the left side of the rounded buttress below the large scoop and upper headwall. From a hard to see slot (for the left hand), climb an assortment of polished and sloping cobbles, small pockets/scoops, and edges to a very large coarse-grained inclusion. Continue up the lower angled slab to the aforementioned headwall. Pull the headwall on edges, a great inclusion, and shallow scoops & pockets, to an anchor above the ledge.
content.location: Left of the trail as the trail goes uphill into the First Corridor. Slotterhouse is the 2nd route from the left on the Egg Cup buttress. Identified by a vertical 4-finger slot for the left hand about 7 feet above the base, and is the second line of bolts from the left.

content.description: Head up slightly chossy rock, just right of the chimney, to the first bolt below the overhang. Start cranking difficult moves to get past the overhang and established on the steep face above. Continue up tricky, moderately difficult climbing past more bolts to a spooky move going from the overhang face to the slab above. Shade in the morning.
content.location: This route starts just right of Egg-zillaration.

content.description: Head up and left thru a low angle bowl, then up the steeper left side of the bowl to the anchor on the ledge.
content.location: Starts uphill  8'- 10' left of Slotterhouse. Far left route on the Egg Cup.

content.description:
"The Green Mile" climbs the wonderfully pocketed steep face on the far right side of The Egg Cup buttress. It is easily seen to the left as one walks up the trail into the shady First Corridor.

Climb the face left of the rounded flake on splendid pockets to a high 1st bolt. Continue up and right following the line of pockets to a large inclusion on the left. The pockets end and the face bulges out to yield a committing crux on small fingery edges, then more pockets to a last bolt and a series of awesome moves to an anchor on the headwall above the ledge.
content.protection: 6 bolts & 2-ring Fixe anchor on the upper headwall.
content.location: Left of the trail as you pass The Egg on the approach to the First Corridor proper. Just left of the rounded flake that forms the left edge of the huge hueco or solution pocket at the base of the east face of The Egg.

content.description: Ascend the west face of The Egg, past 5 bolts. Chimney or stem up the gap between The Egg and the west wall of Texas Canyon to reach the 1st bolt. Pull pockets over the bulge, moving left to right on steep featured rock to the top of The Egg. Beware of loose rock and the poison oak at the base of this route and on either end of the gap between The Egg and the west wall of Texas Canyon.
content.protection: 5 bolts to 2-open shuts 20 ft. below  the summit.  There are three sets of  anchors on the summit of The Egg. A pair of bolts with OLD rusted chains on the NE shoulder, above "Exhilaration,"  a set of open shuts low on the west shoulder, and a set of Fixe rings below the summit on the south face, for "Egg-Nostic."
content.location: Egg-zillaration is on the west face of The Egg.

content.description: Egg-nostic climbs to the summit of The Egg via the right side of  the scoop and overhang, above the ledge between the Egg Cup Buttress and the top of The Egg. From the anchor for Boneyard & Texas Chainsaw, mantle onto the lower portion of the scoop and climb the slab to the 1st bolt. Continue either straight up on pockets and features to the lip of the overhang, or move right from the bolt on small pockets, pull the overhang to better, deep pockets and knobs above the lip. Continue up the knobby upper face to the anchor, below the summit.
content.location: Egg-nostic is an extension to Boneyard and begins at the Boneyard/ Texas Chainsaw anchor, above the ledge that splits the upper and lower portions of The Egg.

content.description: Climb the left side of a blunt pillar past a bolt. Step up off the pillar, clip a bolt and make a difficult move to the right (crux). Continuously tricky and engaging pockets and edges lead to a good stance at the chain anchor.
content.location: Starts 5' to the right of Green Mile.

climbs.name: Boneyard
climbs.fa: Jeffrey Thomas, Sandy Champagne, Pamela Neal, & Ben Chapman (May 2011)

content.description: Begin pulling pockets to a series of large coarse inclusions. As the wall steepens, continue climbing on knobs, small edges, and the occasional pocket. Above the 5th bolt moving to the right, on small polished cobbles for footholds, yields a series of small pockets that lead to the anchor.
content.location:
Located just right of center on the rounded buttress (The Egg Cup) at the base of The Egg.

4th route from the left.

climbs.name: Poached
climbs.fa: TR - Chris Ramirez 11/20,  FL - Tony Sartin 12/2/20

content.description: Climb an easy slab up to the base of the Egg and steeper rock. Boulder up past a pair of bolts to clip a fixed chain draw that protects the crux. A long move gets you to a positive crimp and easier, slabby climbing up to a lower off near the top of the cliff.
content.protection: 7 bolts, 4th has a fixed chain draw, lead to a two bolt, two steel carabiner lower off.
content.location: Poached is on the back side (or west face) of the Egg, 10 feet right of Marshall Law. Shade in the morning, sun in the afternoon.
